ygData.subject: Re: CPPN node bloat
ygData.msgSnippet: I don t think there s a lot of research that aims to solve the problem of non-deterministic fitness in part because many people assume it s a good thing, and

I don't think there's a lot of research that aims to "solve" the problem =
of non-deterministic fitness in part because many people assume it's a good=
 thing, and therefore don't recognize that there is a big problem.  However=
, there is research that looks at the issue in more rigorous detail.  For e=
xample, Shimon Whiteson's paper, "Critical factors in the empirical perform=
ance of temporal difference and evolutionary methods for reinforcement lear=
ning," is an excellent study of the effect of nondeterminism and other fact=
ors on NEAT and SARSA (a value-function-based reinforcement learning algori=
thm):

http://staff.science.uva.nl/~whiteson/pubs/whitesonjaamas09.pdf

In =
particular look at figures 9 and 15.  In figure 9, NEAT rises to a fitness =
of 14 seconds hold time in the traditional nondeterministic Keepaway soccer=
 task.  This figure is actually good, and does better than SARSA at 12.

Bu=
t in figure 15, in a deterministic version of the task, NEAT rises to an am=
azing 200 seconds of hold time!  SARSA on the other hand only rises to abou=
t 25 seconds.

So I think we have to be careful with analyzing the "problem=
" of nondeterminism.  In fact, NEAT is still working relatively well with i=
t, when compared to other (non-evolutionary) algorithms.  Yet when the nond=
eterminism is taken away, NEAT is unstoppable, as if it were unleashed.  Th=
e story is more that determinism is a powerful grease on the wheels of evol=
ution, rather than that nondeterminism is cataclysmic.  (It is also importa=
nt to note that the genome that achieves 200 seconds may not be better in g=
eneral than the one that achieves 14 - I don't think Shimon tested both of =
them in a nondeterministic scenario to find out.)

Personally, I don't thin=
k natural evolution handles noise any better.  Great people constantly die =
young, which of course is absolutely deplorable and can hardly be "good" fo=
r evolution, unless one takes the circular view that anything natural evolu=
tion does is what it's supposed to do.  (That is, if someone died, that mus=
t be good because they weren't fit enough.)  I think a more reasonable inte=
rpretation is that natural evolution succeeded despite being handicapped by=
 noise rather than because it handles it in some elusive way.  If we could =
give everyone in nature a fair shake, the whole thing would probably go a l=
ot faster and smoother.

I would guess that this phenomenon is very general=
.  The more noise, the more chaotic evolution becomes.  Of course, there ar=
e happy mediums.  Sometimes a little noise can help achieve generality at t=
he cost of many evaluations.  Yet if it can be avoided somehow by being mor=
e clever about being deterministic then it should.

I do view it as a resea=
rch challenge.  I am not a big fan of noise because of its deleterious effe=
cts and indeed "deterministic noise" is often better, but I believe there m=
ay be even better ways to get the generality you want without the cost of n=
oise, and I consider it an interesting research question.

ken

hat natural evolution handles

ch has gone into solving this
> problem. I can't think of anything off the =
top of my head.
>

ne else out there have

is sort of a bloat in the

ed, 20 Jan 2010 01:17:26 -0000

oups.com>
> > Subject: [neat] Re: CPPN node bloat
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > Jeff, =
first, if fitness is stagnant, then the system should be increasing the
> >=
 average number of nodes (though not necessarily the number of nodes in the=

> > champ).  In a stagnant situation, you do not have information (i.e. a
=
> > gradient) suggesting which direction is right to go.  Therefore, the mo=
st
> > principled response is to expand your options while never putting al=
l your
> > eggs in one basket.  When fitness is stagnant, we cannot know if=
 further
> > search within the currently dimensionality might eventually fi=
nd a solution,
> > or if the current dimensionality is insufficient and con=
tains no solution at
> > all.  In the latter case, the number of nodes and =
connections would need to
> > ascend to higher dimensionality.  Because we =
do not know which case we are in
> > when stagnation occurs, the best idea =
is to try both:  Some species start
> > arriving with bigger networks while=
 others keep searching in the same old
> > spaces.  Thus, we would expect t=
he *range* of sizes to increase along with the
> > average size.  
> > 
> >=
 Your situation with nondeterminism is probably somewhat similar, causing t=
he
> > average size of solutions to go up because of stagnation.  However, =
because
> > the champion will keep changing with the randomized evaluation,=
 you will
> > observe this phenomenon in the champion itself.  The more noi=
sy it is, the
> > more it is probably observable (i.e. because the more "ra=
ndom" it is who
> > happens to look best at any given time, in effect leadi=
ng to a kind of
> > sampling of the population through the champion).
> > 
=
> > Of course, that may not be a complete explanation for the steep angle o=
f the
> > incline.  I would guess that nondeterminism is also causing a gen=
eral
> > unhealthiness about the evolutionary process overall. Nondetermini=
sm is highly
> > destructive to evolutionary algorithms.  This issue is con=
troversial (even
> > within my own group!) but my personal opinion is one s=
hould avoid
> > nondeterminism unless it is absolutely essential.  For exam=
ple, you can choose
> > a random order of examples but then subject everyon=
e to the same random set -
> > a kind of "deterministic randomness."  Of co=
urse, you are banking on the
> > impartiality of randomness to give you max=
imal generality, but it will often
> > be outweighed by its unhealthy side =
effects on the population.  So I'm
> > guessing that part of the phenomenon=
 is just a side-effect of an inconsistent
> > evaluation scheme leading to =
relative chaos.
> > 
> > There may also be more to it; it merits further in=
vestigation as well.
> > 
> > ken 
> > 
> > 
> >
